results.title: The Ring within [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Eric Michel, ONF | NFB and Dan Bigras
results.brief_description: Dan Bigras, Canadian singer and filmmaker, features in his own documentary along with his extreme fighter friends, Charles Ali Nestor (27 y.o.), David Loiseau (21 y.o.) and Steve Vigneault (22 y.o.) to demonstrate that an outlet can be found for those who find themselves battling with self-destructive impulses or overwhelming uncontrollable anger and rage. Where Bigras uses singing and song-writing as his outlet, his friends prefer to channel their energies into martial arts and extreme fighting as a way of rebuilding their lives. It would seem a common thread runs through the lives of each of these young men as they tell their stories of an unhappy childhood, bullying, teenage gangs, violence and family break-down. But the frankness and honesty in their personal tales and the friendship, loyalty and support between the four men in their collective struggle to transform their anger into a rage for life is what really defines this film, not the fighting scenes - their courage is to be admired. Features interviews with families, friends, sporting personnel and other extreme fighters and includes graphic coverage of bouts from competition fights and training sessions. In English and French with English subtitles. WARNING: CONTAINS GRAPHIC IMAGES OF EXTREME FIGHT SCENES.

results.title: The Ring (Musical score)
results.creator_credit: John Maxwell, British International Pictures and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: Hitchcock’s first film for British International pictures is a foray into virtuoso camera moves, odd angles, ingenious narrative devices and several expressionistic point-of-view sequences. The end result is a love triangle story given the unique Hitchcock treatment. Up and coming boxer, ‘One Round’ Jack Sander suspects his wife, Nelly’s attentions are drifting to those of another - rival champion, Bob Corby. Whereas Sander is young and self assured, Corby is sophisticated and socially aware - attributes that appeal to the young wife, who leaves her husband for him. The film culminates in a showdown between Round One and Corby, the watchful eyes of Nelly on those she has loved and must choose between. The film’s title has several applications - the marriage band, the boxing ring and the secret bracelet from a tryst. The film has been praised for it’s ability to capture social detail, as well as using expressionist visual devices to convey a character’s state of mind (Geoff Andrew). Note: The film has been digitally mastered and features a new music score composed by Neil Brand. Cast includes Carl Brisson, Lilian Hall Davis, Ian Hunter, Forrester Harvey and Gordon Harker.

results.title: The Rigid Heddle Frame
results.creator_credit: Ken J. Widdowson, John Gray and Educational Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Weaving”.
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. In the rigid heddle frame, warp threads are passed through a slotted, wooden heddle instead of being attached to moving cords. Additional credits: photographer: Alan Grice ; script: Kay Donald ; editor: David Corke ; weaver and adviser: Erika Semler.

results.title: The Right whale: an endangered species
results.brief_description: Zoologist Roger Payne, on location in Argentina, discusses the characteristics of the Southern Right Whale, rarest of the great whales, including their feeding and communication habits.

results.title: The Right Track
results.brief_description: A safety film dedicated to teaching youngsters of the need for safety precautions in the vicinity of railroad tracks, property and and yards. Trains fascinate children, but rail tracks are a most dangerous playground. Sponsored by the Association of American Railroads.

results.title: The Right to die
results.brief_description: This film approaches the subject of death in an open manner. The questions which face today’s terminally ill - mercy killing, suicide and medical prolongation of life are scrupulously examined. Frank discussions with patients and interviews with doctors, lawyers, psychiatrists and members of the clergy provide insight and vast differences of opinions to the issues. Important concepts addressed include: when is a person alive or dead; quantity and quality of life; truth and death; criminality in mercy killing; passive versus active euthanasia.

results.title: The Right to choose
results.creator_credit: Wessex Film and Video Productions and Rouk Humphreys
results.brief_description: Begins with a reminder of how the sponsor began its work following the sudden spread of poliomyelitis in the early 1950s, and shows how it is possible for adults to learn to ride despite physical disabilities including cerebral palsy, hemiplegia, paraplegia, amputation and blindness. Intended for people whose work brings them into contact with the medical rehabilitation of the physically disabled.

results.creator_credit: Louise Hubbard, Kay Donovan and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Examines every person’s right to understand what occurs in court regardless of language. The use of interpreters is one way of overcoming this disadvantage.

results.title: The Right stuff
results.creator_credit: The Ladd Company, Warner Bros Pictures, Irwin Winkler, Robert Chartoff and Philip Kaufman
results.brief_description: Based on Tom Wolfe’s best seller, “The Right Stuff” recounts the development of the American Space programme. Spanning 15 years, the film begins with Chuck Yeager breaking the sound barrier and moves on to concentrate primarily on the original seven Mercury astronauts. The film relates the perils and frustrations of the astronauts, their arduous training and complex personal lives, and the absurd lengths to which they must go to satisfy the public’s demand for real heroes. Cast includes Sam Shepard, Scott Glenn, Ed Harris, Dennis Quaid, Fred Ward and Barbara Hershey.

results.title: The Right person for the job
results.brief_description: Excerpts from a seminar held on equal rights legislation held at Trinity College, Melbourne University, are interspersed with dramatisations of problems which women face in the workforce. Shows the role of the conciliation officer and the hearing of a discrimination case by the Equal Opportunity Board
